Whenever firewalls and network security come into play, there is a surprising number of oversight and lack of attention inside small business world. IPCop was designed for this purpose very application (cost-effective firewall solution) and as such it is made for any small business network admin in your mind: The entire OS is tell you a stylish web interface, allowing easy administration with the IPCop firewall from every web-accessible machine, and the installation is straightforward and full of easy-to-understand recommendations.

IPCop is one of several distros, like Smoothwall, which aim to be full-featured firewalls for small business. Unlike Smoothwall and others, however, IPCop is free, thus making the insertion of an IPCop instance in ones network both a painless and extremely cost-effective solution, especially where a dedicated hardware firewall appliance is an expense your business simply cannot afford.

IPCop Disadvantages <br> IPCop does have its disadvantages, of training course, especially when compared for a more robust appliance like a Cisco ASA. It lacks the fine granularity involving IOS, for example, and most of the more advanced ACLs and command-line magic the IOS undergoes is beyond the scope with the IPCop instances. That said, however, IPCop comes very near to the performance of an entry-level ASA, and many of the functions an ASA provides are duplicated effectively with IPCop's web interface.

Linux Distro <br> The title about this article, however, is not necessarily "Best firewall appliance". We're here to talk about cost-effective firewall solutions, and in the regard a Linux-based distro is unbeatable. While it will require some spare hardware, the system requirements can be sparse, and so the setup cost is minimal at best (and the software is, of course, open-source and free). The truth is, even disregarding the amount, I am willing to position forth the semi-controversial proven fact that IPCop may be pretty much a dedicated firewall device in small companies setting; many of the functions the quality of are more than suitable for a very small business network.

That said, no network should be without security; the cost of a firewall appliance, though prohibitive, need not stop a very small business from implementing security options. With open-source, free options like IPCop, a network admin are able to insert a firewall into his network infrastructure at little to 100 % free, immediately making his network more secure and giving him the electricity and functionality of a devoted firewall appliance at a fraction in the price.

IPCop - Cost effective Firewall <br> IPCop, the example we'll use in this article, is an open-source OS based on Linux that was designed to act as a firewall and router. Unlike a vanilla Linux distro going iptables, IPCop goes far beyond simple add together with drop rules; it has features one might expect from a more advanced firewall appliance, including intrusion detection, VPN services, and traffic shaping capability. IPCop was designed for this purpose very application (cost-effective firewall solution) and as such it is made for any small business network admin in your mind: The entire OS is run through a stylish web interface, allowing easy administration in the IPCop firewall from every web-accessible machine, and the installation is straightforward and full of easy-to-understand recommendations. It can be and is being used for sending any kind of data, may that get audio, video or words.
